Research Paper Cooperation of active site isolation and charge transfer in intermetallic Al-Co catalysts boosting the semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene Huibin Liu Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Conceptualization Wenhao Yang Methodology Formal analysis Weilin Shen Investigation Formal analysis Ying Zhong Investigation Formal analysis Wenjun Zhu Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Xiao Chen Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Changhai Liang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals & Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals & Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals & Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The long-term scientific challenge and pursuit for semi-hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes can be satisfied by regulating metal active centers or developing new catalytic materials. Herein, Al-Co x intermetallic catalysts are successfully prepared by reducing metal oxides using LiCl-CaH2 composite molten salts, which are utilized for the semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene. The AlCo intermetallic catalyst with amorphous alumina encapsulation, resulting from the non-stoichiometric ratio feeding, exhibits significantly high styrene selectivity (83 %) at 99 % conversion of phenylacetylene under 100 °C and 0.3 MPa H2, which is much better than those of surface Co-rich samples and Co/Al2O3 catalyst. The selectivity enhancement in phenylacetylene semi-hydrogenation is attributed to the alteration in the adsorption mode of styrene over AlCo intermetallic catalyst surface, which facilitates by the electron-rich and isolated Co active sites. Moreover, in hydrogenation of alkyne with different functional groups and steric hindrances, the corresponding alkene selectivity is similarly satisfactory, and the catalyst is easy to separate and has a stable structure. This work offers a valuable approach for tailoring the catalytic performance of intermetallic compounds formed by transition metal aluminides, and expanding their potential applications in efficient hydrogenation catalysts. Graphical abstract AlCo intermetallic catalyst with amorphous alumina encapsulation exhibits significantly high styrene selectivity (83 %) at 99 % conversion of phenylacetylene, which is much better than those of surface Co-rich sample and Co/Al2O3 catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Semi-hydrogenation Intermetallic compound Molten salt Active site isolation Charge transfer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenation of alkynes is a key reaction in modern chemical production. The semi-hydrogenated products, alkenes, serve as important monomers that are essential in the production process of various fine chemicals, such as perfumes, vitamins, synthesis of resins and pharmaceuticals et al. [1,2]. The efficient selective hydrogenation of a typical terminal alkyne, phenylacetylene (PA), holds significant importance not only in investigating reaction mechanisms but also in industrial production [3,4]. Styrene (ST), the semi-hydrogenated product of PA, is widely used as a vital chemical intermediate in the production of synthetic rubber, pesticides, and polymers. However, the hydrogenation of PA is a continuous reaction, and the target product ST is easily hydrogenated to ethylbenzene (EB) [5]. A strategy that has proven to be very effective in improving the selectivity of ST is the adjustment of the geometry and electronic structure of the active metal, which can reduce the adsorption energy of the intermediate product ST and increase the hydrogenation energy barrier of ST [6–8]. The Lindlar catalyst, modified with lead or quinoline on noble metal Pd, are considered as the benchmark for selective hydrogenation of alkynes [9]. However, due to the sacrifice of a significant amount of the active phase and the utilization of toxic compounds, this strategy is considered environmentally unfriendly and inefficient in terms of atom efficiency [2,10]. Intermetallic compounds (IMCs) offer unparalleled advantages over single-metal systems in the controllable adjustment of the geometric and electronic structure of active metallic sites, thereby allowing intermetallic compounds composed of non-noble metal elements to exhibit catalytic performance comparable to noble metals [11,12]. In addition, intermetallic catalysts with specific geometries provide an ideal model for gaining insight into the interactions between the catalyst and the reactant molecules [13–15]. In comparison to carbon, silicon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and boron, aluminum exhibits a higher density of free electrons, consequently, which can bond with transition metals to form aluminides and donate more electron to metals, showing distinct catalytic properties [16–18]. In previous studies, Armbrüster et al. synthesized Al13Fe4 IMC using the arc-melting, which exhibited highly hydrogenation activity and ethylene selectivity comparable to the precious metal Pd in hydrogenation of acetylene [19]. Similarly, Al13Co4 IMC with efficient separation of Co sites showed excellent catalytic activity and stability in the preparation of butene via selective hydrogenation of butadiene [20]. Zięba et al. prepared Al5Fe2 and Al5Co2 ribbons using a melt-spinning process, also showing alkynes hydrogenation activity with 70 % selectivity for ST at 80 % PA conversion [21]. Nevertheless, the high temperature (>900 °C) required to overcome kinetic energy barrier of atomic diffusion and ordering leads to sintering of metal materials, significantly reducing the catalyst's surface area, which significantly impacting the efficient utilization of aluminide catalysts. In our previous research, Al-Ni IMCs were synthesized using a wet chemistry method, exhibiting satisfactory high selectivity and catalytic stability in the selective hydrogenation of naphthalene [22]. However, the difficult-to-remove by-products and templating agents inherited from wet chemistry may block active sites and mask the activity-structure relationship [23]. Due to the smaller negative potential of non-precious metals compared to precious metals, and the strong oxygen affinity of main group metal Al [24], preparing size-controlled and composition-controlled non-precious transition metal aluminides is a major challenge [25]. The low-temperature molten salt method provides a reference for preparing Al-based catalytic materials with high specific surface area and uniform structure [26,27]. This method has been proven to be a bottom-up synthesis approach and has been applied in the production of various nano-alloy powders [28,29]. In addition, IMCs or alloy prepared using this method have been demonstrated to have the advantages of high specific surface areas, simple operation, and good repeatability [27,30]. Therefore, the molten salt synthesis strategy is expected to become a versatile and controllable synthesis method for Al-based IMCs. The objective of this study is to adjust the electronic properties and ensemble of Co by forming Al-Co IMCs, thereby altering the hydrogenation activity and catalytic selectivity of Co. The Al-Co IMCs with different catalyst structure models are prepared by using a LiCl-CaH2 composite molten salt to reduce metal oxides in an argon atmosphere at 600 °C. Subsequently, the prepared catalysts are applied to the hydrogenation of PA, and the results indicate that the Al-Co0.67 sample with the AlCo phase exhibits the highest ST selectivity (83 %) when the PA conversion exceeded 99 %. The in-situ characterization and theoretical computational simulations reveal the enhanced effect of efficiently isolated Co sites with special charger transfer on the semi-hydrogenation of PA to ST. This work offers theoretical support and practical guidance for the controlled synthesis of non-precious metal aluminide catalysts and their application in the field of alkynes selective hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Co(NO3)2·6H2O (AR), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (AR), NH₄Cl (AR), and (NH₄)₂CO₃ (AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. LiCl (AR), CaH2 (metals basis), activated aluminum oxide, PA (AR), ST (AR), and ethanol (AR) were purchased from Aladdin. All chemical reagents were used without further purification. The gases including H2 (>99.999 %), Ar (>99.999 %), and 10 vol % H2/Ar were supplied from Dalian Special Gases Co., Ltd. Deionized water (Milli-Q System) was used in the experiment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Preparation of Al-Co x (pre) Oxides Precursors: The oxide precursors were prepared by a simple co-precipitation method. The precipitating agent (NH4)2CO3 solution (1 M) was slowly added to a vigorously stirred solution containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.16–0.07 M) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (0.13–0.05 M) with different molar ratios under agitation, the precipitation pH was controlled to be 8.5–9. After stirring overnight, the resulting pink solid was obtained through rotary evaporation. The obtained solid was dried in an 80 °C oven for 10 h, followed by calcination at 550 °C in air for 2 h to obtain oxides named as Al-Co x (pre), where x represents the molar ratios of Co/Al. Preparation of Al-Co x Catalysts: The Al-Co x IMCs catalysts are prepared by LiCl-CaH2 composite molten salt method. The Al-Co x (pre), CaH2, and LiCl were mixed in a mortar in the glovebox according to the weight ratios of precursor/CaH2/LiCl = 1/4/3. The well-milled powder was transferred to a corundum crucible, and then placed in a quartz tube furnace at 600 °C under a flowing argon atmosphere (40 mL min−1) for reduction for 3 h. The reduced black block was taken out after natural cooling to room temperature, and then washed with 1 M NH₄Cl aqueous solution and deionized water until the pH = 7, then vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 10 h to obtain the powder of Al-Co x catalysts, where x represented the molar ratios of Co/Al. Preparation of Co/Al2O3 Catalyst: The supported catalyst (Co/Al2O3, 20 wt.%) was prepared through a simple impregnation method. First, 2.5 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water, and subsequently 2 g activated alumina was added to the solution, and impregnated with stirring for 10 h. A pink solid was obtained after rotary evaporation at 50 °C. The obtained pink solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 8 h and then oxidized at 400 °C for 3 h under 50 % O2/Ar with flow 80 mL min−1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterizations of the samples were carried out using a Rigaku Smartlab-9 kW diffractometer equipped with a K-beta filter and a Cu Kα1 (45 kV, 200 mA) monochromatized radiation source. The particle size and shape of the samples were observed using an electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU8220) with a 20 kV acceleration voltage. The elemental composition and microstructure were determined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-F200) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using an Autosorb-iQ instrument (Quantachrome) to determine specific surface area of the powders. The sample was degassed at 300 °C under a pressure of 10−3 Torr for 8 h. The metal contents in the catalysts were characterized by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 2000 DV, PerkinElmer). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on the Axis Supra+ electron spectrometer using a monochromatic Al Ka (1486.6 eV) X-ray source with a power of 150 W (HV=15 kV, I = 10 mA). A 5 kV Ar+ ion gun was employed for surface cleaning/etching of the samples. The C 1 s line (284.8 eV) was used as reference energy. The magnetic properties of prepared samples were characterized using the Physical Property Measurement System PPMS-DynaCool (Quantum Design, USA). Magnetic hysteresis loops were recorded under applied magnetic fields ranging from −20 to 20 kOe at room temperature (300 K). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed using the AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer with a thermal conductivity detector. The IR spectra data of the adsorbed PA and ST on the catalyst were collected using a diffuse reflectance Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer (DRIFTS, Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50) equipped with a Harrick in situ cell diffuse reflectance accessory and MCT/A detector. The data were analyzed using OMNIC software. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation A 100 mL stainless steel reaction vessel (BKWK-100, Shanghai) equipped with an electric stirrer was used as the hydrogenation reactor. All catalysts needed to be activated before the reaction, with activation conditions at 500 °C for 2 h in a 50 % H2/Ar (80 mL min−1) flowing atmosphere. The hydrogenation reaction was carried out at 100 °C under a 0.3 MPa H2 atmosphere with mechanical stirring (800 rpm). Typically, 0.6 g PA, 160 mg catalyst, and 0.6 g n-octane (used as an internal standard for analysis) were mixed in 50 mL ethanol. After filtering the reaction products, gas chromatography (Agilent GC-8890) was used to analyze the content of each component in the samples. The carbon balance of the products was within the range of 100 ± 3 %. Conversion of PA and selectivity to ST were calculated based on the following equations: (1) Conversion ( % ) = n 0 − n re n 0 × 100 % (2) Selectivity ( n i , % ) = n i ∑ n i × 100 % Where n0 and nre are the initial and final concentration of PA, respectively, where ni refers to the concentrations of the different products (mol·L−1). The reaction rate constant ka was calculated by the reaction rates equation and assuming pseudo-first-order kinetics as following (3) d c a dt = k a × c a (4) ln 1 1 − x a = k a × t Where ca is concentration (mol·L−1), ka is the rate constant (min−1), t is reaction time, and xa is conversion. The consumption rate was calculated by the following equation: (5) r = n c t × m Where nc represents the consumption of PA or ST (mol), t is reaction time (min), m is molar amount of Co in the catalyst (mol), r consumption rate (mmolPA or ST·molCo −1·min−1). 2.4 DFT calculations The first-principles calculations for the slab model were conducted using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [31,32]. The Kohn–Sham equations is solved using a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) employing the projected augmented wave method (PAW) [33,34] and with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhoff (PBE) [35] generalized function. The van der Waals interactions were considered by the Grimme's DFT-D3 correction [36]. All DFT calculations were performed with a cutoff energy of 400 eV. The convergence criteria for force and electronic self-consistent were set to below 0.05 eV Å−1 on each atom and 10−4 eV, respectively. The calculation is performed using a 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-point sampling in the Brillouin zone. Further details are given in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization A series of metal oxide precursors are prepared by the co-precipitation method, and named Al-Co2 (pre), Al-Co1.5 (pre), Al-Co1 (pre), Al-Co0.67 (pre) and Al-Co0.5 (pre). As shown in Fig. S1, the metal oxides exhibit the CoAl2O4 spinel structure. Subsequently, the Al-Co x (pre) precursor is reduced using a composite molten salt in a flowing argon gas atmosphere at 600 °C. The composite molten salt system creates a deoxidizing and strongly reducing condition, enabling the reduction of Al-Co x (pre) with strong oxygen affinity. This is attributed to the fact that CaH2 exhibits strong reducing properties in the molten state of LiCl. During this process, the Al-Co x (pre) undergoes the following steps: metal reduction, diffusion, nucleation, and aggregation, as illustrated in Scheme 1 . The reaction equation for the reduction of metal oxides by CaH2 is shown in Eqs. (6)-(8). (6) C o A l 2 O 4 + C a H 2 + 2 L i C l → C o + 2 A l L i O 2 + C a C l 2 + H 2 (7) 2 C o + 2 A l L i O 2 + 3 C a H 2 + C a C l 2 → 2 A l C o + 2 L i C l + 4 C a O + 3 H 2 (8) Overall : C o 2 A l O 4 + C a H 2 → A l C o + C a O + H 2 In comparison to Al (−1.7 V vs SHE) [37], Co with a higher standard reduction potential [38] (−0.28 V vs SHE) undergoes the reduction by a composite molten salt firstly, forming metallic Co. Subsequently, during the annealing process, the reduced metallic Al and Co spontaneously nucleate, aggregate, and grow, forming the Al-Co x IMCs. A series of catalysts are synthesized by reducing Al-Cox (pre) with different Al/Co molar ratios, and named as Al-Co2, Al-Co1.5, Al-Co1, Al-Co0.67 and Al-Co0.5. As shown in Fig. 1 a, both cubic phases of AlCo IMC and metallic Co are observed in the Co-rich samples (Al-Co1.5 and Al-Co2). Co atoms exceeding the stoichiometric ratio of AlCo IMC undergo segregation and aggregation into metallic Co particles during the annealing process of the sample, resulting in the final powder sample becoming a mixed phase of Co and AlCo. In the powder XRD patterns of Al-Co1 and Al-Co0.67 samples, the AlCo phase becomes the predominant component, and a small amount of Al(OH)3 is observed in the Al-Co0.67 sample as shown in Fig. 1b. With the decrease in the Co/Al molar ratios, the diffraction peaks associated with the Al(OH)3 gradually strengthen. In the powder XRD pattern of the Al-Co0.5 sample, the diffraction peaks related to the AlCo phase almost vanish, while the Al(OH)3 phase becomes the predominant component. The crystalline phase compositions of different samples are shown in Table 1 . Therefore, the Al-Co0.5 sample may undergo decomposition during the cleaning process, resulting in oxidation and the formation of Al(OH)3. The variation in element ratios is also supported by ICP-OES (Table 1). The ICP results indicate that the molar ratio of Al/Co in all samples is higher than the theoretical feed ratio, which attributed to the partial removal of Co not bonded with Al during the NH4Cl aqueous solution cleaning process, resulting in the loss of Co element. However, in the Co-rich samples, the Co element content remains significantly higher than the stoichiometric ratio of AlCo IMC. This is attributed to the greater stability of bulk metallic Co compared to nano-sized Co particles. The structure and morphology of the synthesized catalysts particles are further characterized using SEM and N2 adsorption-desorption. As show in Fig. 2a-e, the catalysts particles prepared using the molten salt method exhibit agglomerated states, appearing approximately spherical. Interestingly, in the Co-rich samples (Al-Co2, Al-Co1.5, and Al-Co1), small particles with aggregation of are observed on the particle surface (enlarged detail view in the upper right corner of the image). However, in the Al-rich samples (Al-Co0.67 and Al-Co0.5), no aggregated small particles can be observed on the surface. Combined with the XRD and ICP-OES results, the small particles observed on the surface of Co-rich samples may be attributed to two cases: the segregation of Co elements due to non-stoichiometric ratio and the enrichment of Co atoms due to the oxidation of Al atoms. Fig. S2 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions of the oxide precursors and the catalysts reduced by CaH2. The calculated physical values are summarized in Table S1. The specific surface area of oxide precursors is lower than that of the catalysts reduced by CaH2, and both samples exhibit a gradual decrease in specific surface area with increasing Co content. This is attributed to the fact that Co particles are more easily aggregated and less susceptible to oxidation and decomposition in the aluminum-cobalt system. Significant hysteresis loops are observed in the Al-Co0.5 sample, and Al-Co0.5 sample possessed the largest specific surface area of 244 m2·g−1 (Table S1). The high specific surface area of the Al-rich sample is contributed by the loosely structured amorphous oxides formed from the oxidation of aluminum during the cleaning process. To understand the impact of different Co/Al molar ratios on the particle structure and elemental uniformity of synthesized catalysts. The HRTEM and HAADF-STEM images of catalysts synthesized at different molar ratios, along with their EDXS mappings are shown in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3a-c, the HRTEM images of Co-rich samples (Al-Co2, Al-Co1.5, and Al-Co1), the lattice spacing of 0.202 nm and 0.165 nm are assigned to AlCo (110) and (111) facet, respectively. In addition, the cubic-phase Co (200) and (111) facets are also found in Al-Co2, Al-Co1.5 samples. The corresponding EDXS mapping shows the segregation and aggregation of Co particles in Al-Co2 and Al-Co1.5. In Al-Co1 sample the distribution of Co and Al elements is not uniform, suggesting that the sample may have undergone some decomposition, forming a mixture of aluminum oxide and Co. As show in Fig. 3d, in the HRTEM image of the Al-Co0.67 sample, the lattice spacing of 0.286 nm matches the theoretical value for the AlCo (100) facet. Additionally, in the TEM image of the sample, an amorphous oxide layer is observed surrounding the particles. The corresponding EDXS mapping reveals that the Al-Co0.67 sample exhibits a core-shell structure, with the core composed of the AlCo IMC and the shell composed of aluminum oxide. This is attributed to the selective oxidation resulting from the difference oxygen affinities of Al and Co atoms. Even in metal intermetallic systems such as Al-Ni [26], Al-Co [25,42], and Al-Fe [19,43] with strong metallic covalent bonds, surface Al atoms still undergo partial oxidation, which is thermodynamically permissible [25,44]. However, in the non-stoichiometric Al-Co0.67 sample, excess Al atoms initially oxidize to form a loose oxide layer, creating a protective barrier on the surface of the AlCo intermetallic phase. This will inhibit deeper oxidation of the material and atomic diffusion, thus preserving the integrity of the intermetallic phase [45]. This conclusion is further confirmed by the EDXS line scan analysis and TEM of Al-Co0.67 sample, as shown in Fig. S3. In the Al-Co0.5 sample (Fig. 3e), lattice spacing values corresponding to the (200) facet of cubic-phase metallic Co are observed, along with a lattice spacing value of 0.249 nm corresponding to the (104) facet of Al2O3. Combining the EDXS mapping analysis and the XRD pattern of the reduced Al-Co0.5 sample (Fig. S4), it is evident that the Al-Co0.5 sample is a mixture of Al2O3 and Co. To comprehensively analyze the structural changes of the catalyst synthesized via molten salts and the efficient site separation effect of Al atoms on Co atoms, the magnetic properties of samples with different Co/Al ratios were examined. The saturation magnetization per gram of each sample was normalized, as shown in Fig. 3f. All samples are saturated under an applied magnetic field of 20 KOe, showing characteristics of hard magnetism. The saturation magnetization strengths of Al-Co2, Al-Co1.5, Al-Co1, Al-Co0.67, and Al-Co0.5 are 63, 45, 30, 20, and 22 emu/g, respectively. The results indicate that the saturation magnetization strength of samples with different Co/Al ratios gradually increases with the higher Co content, which attributed to the increasing ensemble of Co with the rise in Co quantity [46,47]. Compared to other samples, the Al-Co0.67 exhibits the highest coercivity of 728 Oe. This is attributed to the fact that Al-Co0.67 has a more complete crystalline organization of AlCo IMC. Conversely, when Al and Co atoms fail to form a continuous crystalline phase, the presence of Co or Al oxides in the form of impurities will reduce coercivity [48,49]. The above results indicate that the formation of AlCo IMC leads to a decrease in the coordination number of Co, reducing the ensemble of Co [49]. In summary, the structural transformations of the synthesized catalysts particles due to different Co/Al ratios are shown in Fig. 3g. The Co-rich samples (Al-Co2, Al-Co1.5, and Al-Co1) show the presence of Co elemental segregation and agglomeration on the surface, and Al-rich samples (Al-Co0.67 and Al-Co0.5) show the presence of Al oxides on the surface layer. When the Co/Al molar ratio is 0.67, the synthesized Al-Co0.67 sample exhibits a core-shell structure with alumina encapsulation. H2-TPR measurements were employed for characterizing the chemical state of surface Co species in the material. As shown in Fig. 4 , the reduction peaks at 340 °C in the Co/Al2O3 sample can be attributed to the reduction of the surface-loaded CoO clusters on the support, and the reduction peaks around 470 oC and 620 °C can be assigned to the reduction of CoOx particles that have strong interactions with the support. Compared to other samples, the Al-Co0.67 sample exhibits the highest reduction temperature of Co species at 547 °C, and this reduction peak is attributed to the reduction of Al-Co-O species under the alumina shell. In the Al-Co2 sample, the reduction peak at 440 oC is related to the large bulk of CoO on the material surface. The reduction peaks at 470–492℃ in the Al-Co1.5 and Al-Co1 samples are associated with CoO weakly interacting with the bulk AlCo IMC. In the Al-Co0.5 sample, a broad reduction peak appears at 456 °C, resulting from the decomposition of the sample, leading to the formation of alumina encapsulating both coated and uncoated CoO. 3.2 Catalytic performance for selective hydrogenation of PA A structure-sensitive reaction, the selective hydrogenation of PA to ST, was employed as a probe reaction to evaluate the hydrogenation activity of the prepared catalysts. The reaction path for the hydrogenation of PA is presented Scheme 2 . The hydrogenation of PA was conducted in a 50 mL stainless-steel autoclave over different catalysts. The influence of the reactor wall on the hydrogenation of PA was tested without any catalyst. The results show that at 0.3 MPa, 100 ℃, for 5 h, the conversion of PA is <1 %. ST and EB are the only detected products, and there is no evidence to suggest dealkylation (to toluene) or condensation steps in the reactions on the prepared catalysts. The relationship between the conversion of PA and reaction time is depicted in Fig. 5 a, illustrating the varied catalytic performance of samples with different Co/Al ratios in the hydrogenation of PA. Compared to the Al-rich samples (Al-Co0.67 and Al-Co0.5), the Co-rich samples (Al-Co1, Al-Co1.5, and Al-Co2) completed the hydrogenation of PA in a shorter time. Compared to other samples, Al-Co0.5 sample exhibits the lowest PA hydrogenation activity, with PA conversion below 30 % after a reaction time of 500 min. The hydrogenation activity increases in the following order: Al-Co1.5 (0.22 mmolPA·gcat −1·min−1) > Al-Co1 (0.19 mmolPA·gcat −1·min−1) > Al-Co2 (0.17 mmolPA·gcat −1·min−1) > Al-Co0.67 (0.09 mmolPA·gcat −1·min−1) > Al-Co0.5 (0.02 mmolPA·gcat −1·min−1). However, there is no consistency between the selectivity trend of ST and the PA hydrogenation activity trend of the samples. As show in Fig. 5b, compared to other samples, Al-Co0.67 exhibits the highest ST selectivity, maintaining ST selectivity above 83 % even when the PA conversion exceeds 99 %. However, in Co-rich samples such as Al-Co1, Al-Co1.5 and Al-Co2, the ST selectivity rapidly decreases (all falling below 75 %) when the PA conversion exceeds 99 %. Although Co-rich samples (Al-Co1, Al-Co1.5, and Al-Co2) exhibit higher hydrogenation catalytic activity, the ST selectivity is lower compared to that over Al-Co0.67 sample. This is attributed to the segregation and aggregation of surface Co atoms in the sample, leading to an increase in the surface metallic Co (as show in Fig. 2), The enhancement of hydrogenation catalytic activity leads to a decrease in ST selectivity. To confirm this point, the PA hydrogenation reactions were conducted using Co/Al2O3 catalyst with a Co loading of 20 wt.% and Al-Co0.67 (pre), respectively, at 100 °C in a 0.3 MPa H2. The purpose is to compare the influence of surface metallic Co in the catalysts. The structures of Co/Al2O3 and Al-Co0.67 (pre) samples after reduction in hydrogen at 500 °C for 2 h were characterized by XRD as shown in Fig. S5. Typical diffraction peaks of metal Co is observed in the reduced Al-Co0.67 (pre) and Co/Al2O3 samples. As shown in Fig. 5a-c, the Co/Al2O3 catalyst shows selectivity of 80 % to ST at a PA conversion below 50 %. However, when the PA conversion exceeds 50 %, ST selectivity of the Co/Al2O3 catalyst rapidly decreases to about 25 %, while the generation of the by-product EB increases rapidly. This is attributed to the fact that alkyne molecules (carbon-carbon triple bonds) can bind more strongly to the surfaces of most catalysts than alkene molecules (carbon-carbon double bonds), leading to a higher coverage of alkyne molecules on the catalyst surface [1]. In addition to this, the Al-Co0.67 (pre) sample not only exhibits poor PA hydrogenation activity (0.005 mmolPA·gcat −1·min−1) but also low selectivity of 80 % for the semi-hydrogenated product ST. The molar consumption of PA per minute per mole of Co is employed to describe the reaction activity of different catalysts (Table 2 ), Co/Al2O3 (8.7 mmolPA·molCo −1·min−1) > Al-Co1 (5.4 mmolPA·molCo −1·min−1) > Al-Co1.5 (5.1 mmolPA·molCo −1·min−1) > Al-Co2 (3.6 mmolPA·molCo −1·min−1) > Al-Co0.67 (2.8 mmolPA·molCo −1·min−1) > Al-Co0.5 (0.6 mmolPA·molCo −1·min−1). The Co atoms in the supported catalyst Co/Al2O3 exhibit the highest activity, thanks to the efficient dispersion of metallic Co on the surface of Al2O3, exposing more active sites. Although the Co content in the Al-Co1 sample is lower than in Al-Co1.5 and Al-Co2, Al-Co1 exhibits higher catalytic activity per mole of Co atoms than the Co-rich samples Al-Co1.5 and Al-Co2. This might be attributed to surface decomposition in the Al-Co1 sample, forming a mixture of Co and Al2O3 on the surface and consequently exposing more Co as active site. The decrease in hydrogenation activity observed in the Al-Co1.5 and Al-Co2 samples may result from the segregation of excess Al atoms on the surface, leading to the formation of Al2O3 that covers part of well-ordered AlCo intermetallic surface. In non-stoichiometric AlCo IMC, light metals may segregate and accumulate on the surface during the nucleation and growth process of particles, and forming oxide inclusions during subsequent processing. In summary, the outstanding catalytic activity and ST selectivity of the Al-Co0.67 sample can be attributed to the AlCo IMC encapsulated beneath the alumina shell. The medium binding strengths of alkenes on most metal surfaces results in a high hydrogenation reaction rate of alkenes, which makes it difficult to achieve high selectivity for alkenes. Therefore, kinetic control is an effective way to obtain highly selectivity of alkene [1]. The reaction rate constants (ka (min−1)) for hydrogenation of PA and ST are calculated, as show in Fig. 5d and e and Table 2. The linearity of -ln(1-xa) with reaction time (t) indicates that the hydrogenation reactions of PA or ST over different catalysts follow pseudo-first-order kinetics. The k2/k1 ratio of different catalysts decreased in the following order: Co/Al2O3 (6.9) > Al-Co0.5 (3.8) > Al-Co1 (3.7) > Al-Co2 (3.6)> Al-Co1.5 (2.4) > Al-Co0.67 (2.3). In comparison with other sample, Al-Co0.67 exhibits the smallest k2/k1 ratio, indicating the effective suppression of the ST hydrogenation process on the surface of AlCo IMC. In addition, we compared several published non-precious metal catalysts, including monometallic, bimetallic, and alloy catalysts. The results demonstrate that the Al-Co0.67 catalyst exhibits superior styrene selectivity at high PA conversion (Table S2). In summary, the Al-Co0.67 catalyst with AlCo IMC phase exhibits a positive effect on the selective hydrogenation of PA. This influence is not only proven by the enhanced ST selectivity in Table 2 but also exhibits in higher ST selectivity than other catalysts in the conversion range of 1–99 %, as shown in Fig. 5b. 3.3 Investigations on structure-property correlation of AlCo intermetallic catalyst It is interesting to explore how the incorporation of Al atoms into Co systems results in specific intermetallic structures and influences distinct catalytic behaviors. To this end, the positive role of AlCo intermetallic phases in the process of selectively hydrogenating of PA was revealed using XPS surface cleaning techniques, in-situ DRIFTS, and DFT calculations. Due to the strong oxygen affinity causing unavoidable surface oxidation, Ar+ ion etching was employed to remove surface oxide layers for XPS analysis, aiming to investigate the electron transfer between Al and Co atoms. As shown in Fig. 6 , the XPS spectra of Al-Co0.67 and Al-Co0.5 samples reveal characteristic signals of Al and Co. Using XPS-Peak software, the Co 2p XPS spectrum was deconvoluted into eight peaks (Fig. 6a and b), corresponding to Co0, Co2+, Co3+, and satellite peaks [50,51]. The Al 2p orbitals were deconvoluted into two peaks, attributed to Al0 and Al+ [19,52]. It can be observed from Al-Co0.67 sample in Fig. 6a, the area of the peaks belonging to Co0 gradually increases with the etching time, indicating the contribution of oxides decreases with the increase in etching depth. Compared with the Al-Co0.67 sample, the Co° content in the Al-Co0.5 sample is lower than the oxidized states Co2+ and Co3+(Table S3). This is attributed to Al-Co0.5 being a mixture of Al2O3 and Co (as shown in Fig. S4), with Al2O3 encapsulating dispersed Co. Moreover, compared with the metal Co0 binding energy of 778.1 eV [53] and the Al-Co0.5 sample, the peak position of Co0 in the Al-Co0.67 sample shifted towards lower binding energy by about 0.6 eV. This suggests that in the Al-Co0.67 catalyst with the core AlCo IMC phase, Co metal is in an electron-rich state (Coδ−), indicating an interaction between Al-Co atoms resulting in electron movement. Previous studies have shown that changes in the electronic states of transition metals can influence the adsorption capacity between the catalyst and reaction intermediates [13]. The Al 2p spectra of Al-Co0.67 and Al-Co0.5 are shown in Fig. 6c and d, revealing distinct changes during the etching process. In the Al-Co0.5 sample, even with an etching time for 240 s, the Al 2p orbitals still exhibit AlO x , and no peak attributed to Al0 is observed. In stark contrast, as the etching time increases, a clear peak corresponding to the Al0 species emerges in the Al 2p spectrum of the etched Al-Co0.67 sample [53,54]. Furthermore, with the increased etching time, this peak undergoes a slight shift towards higher binding energy, as shown in Fig. 6c. It is not entirely possible to avoid oxides during the XPS analysis process, especially for powder samples containing Al elements with a strong oxygen affinity. This is due to the exposure of samples to ambient air and the relatively high pressure in the XPS chamber (10−8 Torr) [55], resulting in the inevitable formation of aluminum oxides through the reaction of trace oxygen with Al atoms. The charge transfer between Co and Al is consistent with the electronegativity of Al (1.6) and Co (1.9), and a similar change in the distinctive electronic structure is observed in other intermetallic structures containing transition metals, such as Co-In [56], Ni-In [57], and Ni-Zn [58]. Additionally, the depth analysis of major elements by XPS, as shown in Table S3. As the etching depth increases, the molar ratio of Co/Al in the Al-Co0.67 sample is equal to 1/1, which is close to the theoretical molar ratio of AlCo IMC. DFT calculations further reveal the electron transfer and structural changes in AlCo IMC. Structural models of Co and AlCo IMC are constructed and optimized based on XRD results, as illustrated in Fig. 7 a and b. The electronic structures of monometallic Co and AlCo IMC are compared through the study of three-dimensional electron density difference charges. It can be found that the polarization of the Al-Co bond occurs in AlCo IMC, resulting in charge accumulation near Co sites (yellow area in the figure), which is the result of electron transfer from Al atoms to Co atoms, consistent with the XPS results. Additionally, Bader charge analysis (right side of Fig. 7b) indicates that the charge of Co atoms in AlCo IMC increases to 10.7 e, while Al atoms lose 1.7 e transferred to Co, which is consistent with the electronegativity of Al and Co. Consequently, Co atoms in AlCo IMC is in an electron-rich state (Coδ−). Another feature of intermetallic compounds is the isolation of active sites. As shown in Fig. 7c and d, the addition of Al atoms leads to a decrease in the coordination number of Co-Co from 12 in monometallic Co to 8 in AlCo IMC. Moreover, the Co-Co bond length significantly increases from 2.48 Å in monometallic Co to 2.85 Å in AlCo IMC, confirming that the isolating effect of Al reduces the strength of the Co-Co bonds. The rapid desorption of alkene products from the catalyst surface is a crucial prerequisite for achieving high selectivity to alkene. Adjusting the electronic and geometric structure of the metal active centers to decrease the adsorption strength with ST is considered an effective approach to achieve high selectivity to ST [2]. Considering the high selectivity of Al-Co0.67 sample with AlCo phase in PA hydrogenation reaction, we hypothesize that the surface of AlCo IMC plays a crucial role in substrate adsorption. To verify this hypothesis, we conducted in-situ DRIFTS studies using ST and PA as adsorbates (as shown in Fig. 9). The ST temperature-programmed desorption IR spectra of Co/Al2O3 and Al-Co0.67 samples are show in Fig. 8a-d, where typical absorbance bands of styrene for =CH2 anti-symmetrical stretching at 3026–3060 cm−1 and the C = C bonds (≈1630 cm−1) on the vinyl group are detected. A full list of in situ adsorption mode operations is provided in Table S4. Compared to the ST adsorbed on Co/Al2O3 surface, the IR signals of ST adsorption on the Al-Co0.67 sample is weaker. The IR signal intensity of the adsorption mode of ST on the surfaces of both catalysts decreases with increasing temperature. The characteristic peak areas of the CH vibration region (3100–2900 cm−1) are normalized, as shown in Fig. 8e. Most of the ST molecules on the surface of the Al-Co0.67 sample was desorbed at around 70 °C, however, the ST molecules adsorbed on the catalyst Co/Al2O3 was desorbed at around 90 °C. Therefore, the Al-Co0.67 sample with the AlCo phase exhibits weak ST adsorption capacity. Additionally, the adsorption state of the initial reactant PA is related to the competitive adsorption of PA and ST on the catalyst surface [3]. Fig. 8f displays the signals of adsorbed PA substrate on the surfaces of Co/Al2O3 and Al-Co0.67 catalysts. The peak around 2111 cm−1 attributed to the stretching vibration of the CC bonds after clean physical adsorption of the molecules. Compared to the adsorption of PA on Co/Al2O3, the adsorption peak of CC bonds on Al-Co0.67 surface exhibits a blue shift (towards higher wavenumbers). This blue shift can be attributed to PA molecules coordinated on high electron-density Co sites, resulting in adsorption pattern of π-bonded of CC in the Co active sites [3,59], which will improve the selectivity of ST. Therefore, the adsorption of PA (rather than ST) is more favorable in the competitive adsorption process, which may be related to the high selectivity of ST over Al-Co0.67 catalyst. The adsorption energy and adsorption states of products on the catalyst surface can serve as descriptors for describing the catalytic performance of the catalyst [60]. DFT calculations were employed to simulate the adsorption energy of ST on the monometallic metal Co (111) surface and AlCo IMC (110) surface, as well as the three-dimensional differential charge density of ST adsorption on Co (111) and AlCo IMC (110). Molnár et al. previously pointed out that the adsorption modes of alkyne molecules often present as π-bound acetylene (π-complex), di-σ adsorbed acetylene, and multi-σ bonded ethylidyne [61]. Achieving high selectivity of alkene requires increasing the coverage of π-bound adsorption complexes on the catalyst surface and decreasing the σ-bonded adsorption of intermediate alkene molecules. However, continuous sites composed of transition metal atoms tend to preferentially generate a large number of σ-bonded adsorption type molecules [62]. Therefore, a commonly employed approach to enhance alkene selectivity is to block these ensembles through the modification with an inert component, so-called “active site isolation concept” [15]. The calculated electron density difference for ST adsorption on the metal Co (111) surface and AlCo (110) surface is illustrated in Fig. 9 . In comparison to AlCo surface, the monometallic Co surface features numerous continuous Co sites (Fig. 9a-b), resulting in strong adsorption between the unsaturated bonds of ST and the continuous Co sites over the material surface. As shown in Fig. 9c and d, compared to the AlCo (110) surface, there is more electron transfer between ST and the Co (111) surface with continuous Co sites (yellow region). The electrons distribution in the benzene ring region of the ST molecule, which should originally belong to ST molecule, is redistributed and accumulated between the benzene ring and the Co (111) surface under the influence of continuous Co active sites. Additionally, the electrons of the vinyl C = C bonds are attracted by adjacent Co sites, resulting in an adsorption pattern like σ-bonded (as shown in Fig. 9a and c). This type of adsorption will be favorable for further hydrogenation to produce EB. As shown in Fig. 9b and d, Co is isolated by Al as the active site for the hydrogenation reaction, which leads to a decrease in the number of consecutive Co sites and an increase in the Co-Co atomic distance. Consequently, the electron transfer between ST and AlCo surface is reduced, and the electrons in the benzene ring remain accumulated between the C = C bonds of the benzene ring as show in Fig. 9d. Furthermore, because the Al atoms separate and facilitate electron transfer to Co, the adsorption of the vinyl C = C bonds with electron-rich Co sites exhibits a π-bond-like pattern, with vinyl C = C bonds electrons accumulating near the double bond (yellow region in Fig. 9d). Further analysis reveals that the adsorption energy of ST on the AlCo surface is −2.3 eV, while the adsorption energy of ST on the monometallic Co surface is −2.4 eV. This indicates that during the hydrogenation process of PA, ST is less likely to desorb from the Co surface, thereby reducing the selectivity of ST, which is consistent with the in-situ DRIFTS results. In summary, the reasons for achieving high selectivity of ST on AlCo IMC surface are as follows: 1) The lower electronegativity of Al compared to Co result in charge transfer from Al to Co, leading to the generation of Coδ− and weak π adsorption of nucleophilic ST. 2) The formation of Al-Co IMCs leads to the separation of Co atoms, reducing the type of adsorption at multi-σ bonding sites and enhancing the selectivity of ST. 3.4 Stability test and substrates expansion The stability of catalytic performance is also a crucial factor in evaluating catalyst performance. It is noteworthy that the Al-Co0.67 catalyst exhibits excellent stability in the hydrogenation of PA, which maintained >87 % selectivity for ST after seven cycles (Fig. 10 a). Fig. 10b shows the XRD of the used Al-Co0.67 catalyst, which still maintains the AlCo intermetallic phase compared to the fresh catalyst. TEM characterization further analyzed the structural changes as shown in Fig. 10c, the lattice spacing attributed to the AlCo (110) facet is found in the spent catalyst. In addition, due to the ferromagnetic property of AlCo, solid-liquid separation of the used catalyst can be easily achieved by applying a magnetic field (Fig. 10d). Furthermore, the ICP analysis of the catalyst after the reaction reveals that the Co/Al molar ratio is consistent with that of the fresh catalyst (Table S5). In summary, the Al-Co0.67 catalyst demonstrates remarkable catalytic stability in the selective hydrogenation of PA. After proving that Al-Co0.67 sample with AlCo phase is an efficient catalyst, the catalyst is also utilized in the selective hydrogenation of alkyne molecules with various functional groups. Gratifyingly, the Al-Co0.67 catalyst retains its high catalytic activity and selectivity for these substrates in an ethanol solution. Compared to substrates with electron-donating groups, it also exhibits excellent catalytic activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of substrates with electron-withdrawing groups such as 1‑bromo-4-ethynylbenzene and 3-bromoethynylbenzene (shown in Table 3 ). The hydrogenation activity is higher when the substituent is in the 4-position than in the 3-position, which is related to the steric hindrance of substrate adsorption on the catalyst surface. Al-Co0.67 exhibits high catalytic activity and selectivity towards the corresponding alkenes for alkynes with different steric hindrance, such as 1-heptyne, 1,4-butynediol, and diphenylacetylene. Compared to alkynes with benzene rings, the selectivity towards the corresponding alkenes decreases for linear alkynes due to their smaller steric hindrance. To sum up, these findings demonstrate the special catalytic properties of the magnetically separable Al-Co0.67 catalyst in semi-hydrogenation reactions. 4 Conclusion Al-Co x IMCs are successfully synthesized by reducing metal oxides using LiCl-CaH2 composite molten salts under an Ar atmosphere at 600 °C. By adjusting the Co/Al metal molar ratios, surface elemental segregation and oxidation behavior can be controlled, thus enabling the synthesis of AlCo intermetallic catalyst with a loose alumina shell. Compared to other samples, the Al-Co0.67 catalyst with AlCo phase exhibits the highest ST selectivity, maintaining ST selectivity above 83 % even when the PA conversion exceeds 99 %. Combined XPS, in-situ DRIFTS, and DFT calculations results demonstrate that the introduction of Al atoms not only isolate the Co active sites but also transfers electrons to Co atoms. The electron-rich and isolated Co active sites enhance the adsorption of PA and facilitate the desorption of the target product ST, thereby effectively weakening the over-hydrogenation of ST and enhancing the selectivity towards ST. Our strategy demonstrates that aluminum-containing non-precious metal IMCs can serve as efficient catalysts for selective hydrogenation of alkynes. Moreover, this synthetic approach offers a simple pathway for synthesizing highly efficient metal-aluminides heterogeneous catalysts with broad compositions and applications. coredata.dc:description: The long-term scientific challenge and pursuit for semi-hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes can be satisfied by regulating metal active centers or developing new catalytic materials. Herein, Al-Co x intermetallic catalysts are successfully prepared by reducing metal oxides using LiCl-CaH2 composite molten salts, which are utilized for the semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene. The AlCo intermetallic catalyst with amorphous alumina encapsulation, resulting from the non-stoichiometric ratio feeding, exhibits significantly high styrene selectivity (83 %) at 99 % conversion of phenylacetylene under 100 °C and 0.3 MPa H2, which is much better than those of surface Co-rich samples and Co/Al2O3 catalyst. The selectivity enhancement in phenylacetylene semi-hydrogenation is attributed to the alteration in the adsorption mode of styrene over AlCo intermetallic catalyst surface, which facilitates by the electron-rich and isolated Co active sites. Moreover, in hydrogenation of alkyne with different functional groups and steric hindrances, the corresponding alkene selectivity is similarly satisfactory, and the catalyst is easy to separate and has a stable structure. This work offers a valuable approach for tailoring the catalytic performance of intermetallic compounds formed by transition metal aluminides, and expanding their potential applications in efficient hydrogenation catalysts.
